channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Britain Needs Europe
item.description: Boris Johnson, who sees himself as a kind of James Bond against Brussels, has given the "Brexit" campaign a boost.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Remedy for China’s Economic Gloom Has Echoes of Reagan
item.description: “Supply-side structural reform” represents an effort to rejuvenate President Xi Jinping’s faltering plans to overhaul the Chinese economy.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Recruiters talked to job seekers at a job fair in Beijing last month. A whole generation of Chinese youth raised in a roaring economy over the past decade are coming of age in a period of material uncertainty as jobs come less easily.

item.title: Germany to Continue Funding to Establish Provenance of Looted Art
item.description: The country’s culture minister, who is visiting the United States, said that the effort is “what we owe the victims.”
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Monika Grütters, Germany’s culture minister, at the German Oscar nominees reception at the Villa Aurora in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles, last week.

item.title: Protesting Chinese Rule, Tibetan Monk Dies After Setting Himself Ablaze
item.description: It was the first known act of self-immolation in a Tibetan area of China since August.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Exiled Tibetans in Dharamsala, India, on Wednesday marching in support of two Tibetans who were said to have self-immolated in protest of Chinese rule.

item.title: New U.S. General Takes Command of Coalition Forces in Afghanistan
item.description: Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. will lead a combined United States and NATO force of 13,000 troops, replacing Gen. John F. Campbell, who is retiring after a 37-year military career.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Dick Bradsell, Bartender Who Helped Revive London Cocktail Scene, Dies at 56
item.description: Mr. Bradsell’s influence was felt throughout Britain and as far away as Australia thanks to bartenders trained by him or inspired by his creations.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT SIMONSON
item.media:description: The bartender Dick Bradsell in an undated photo.

item.title: Russian Prosecutors Seek 23-Year Prison Term for Ukrainian Pilot
item.description: Nadiya V. Savchenko, a helicopter pilot charged in connection with the deaths of two Russian journalists, has become a symbol in the Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A protest in Moscow last week in support of the Ukrainian military pilot Nadiya V. Savchenko. Ms. Savchenko is charged in connection with the deaths of two Russian journalists who were reporting from eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Cuts Billions in Aid to Lebanon, Opening Door for Iran
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s tactic could allow Iran to increase its role in Lebanon through its ally, the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Supporters listened to Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, in April in Beirut, Lebanon, in front of an image of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

item.title: Egypt’s Parliament Expels Lawmaker Who Dined With Israel’s Ambassador
item.description: The lawmaker, Tawfik Okasha, had already been attacked with a shoe by a fellow lawmaker three days earlier over the same episode, which highlighted Egyptian sensitivity toward Israel.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Tawfik Okasha taped his mouth shut in protest over not being given the floor during a parliamentary session in Cairo in January.

item.title: In Scandal at Puerto Rico Utility, Ex-Fuel Buyer Insists He Took No Bribes
item.description: William Clark led the fuel procurement office at the heart of accusations that the utility overpaid for cheap, dirty oil.
item.dc:creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
item.media:credit: José Jiménez-Tirado for The New York Times
item.media:description: William R. Clark during his testimony at the Puerto Rico Senate’s special commission investigating procedures related to oil purchases at the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority.

item.title: Spain’s Socialist Leader Fails in Effort to Become Prime Minister
item.description: The likelihood increases of new elections in June to help break the deadlock among the nation’s four main parties.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Pedro Sánchez, the leader of Spain’s Socialist party, in the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: With Bet on Japan, Sharp Stumbles
item.description: The plight of the electronics company is a story of missteps by managers who failed to anticipate shifts in the global electronics industry.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: An employee at Sharp, the Japanese consumer electronics company, inspecting an LCD television at a plant in Japan.

item.title: Greece Tries to House Migrants as Other Gates Close
item.description: Camps have been opening in Greece at the rate of nearly one a day to house thousands of migrants who cannot move forward, and cannot or will not go back.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A warehouse in Piraeus, a port city near Athens, that houses migrants. Camps are opening at a rate of nearly one a day.

item.title: Blacklisted in Iran, Gay Poet Seeks Asylum in Israel
item.description: Payam Feili, a poet and novelist, fled to Tel Aviv after government loyalists accused him of immorality and collaborating with the enemy.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Payam Feili in Tel Aviv on Tuesday. “The more I gained a reputation outside Iran, the harder it became for me to live in Iran,” he said.

item.title: Statistics From China Say Coal Consumption Continues to Drop
item.description: The data lends further support to the view that the world’s largest emitter of carbon dioxide may be reaching a peak in coal consumption.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Smoke billowing as men pulled a tricycle in a neighborhood near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi Province.

item.title: Turkey Cracks Down on Insults to President Erdogan
item.description: The justice minister revealed that 1,845 cases of insult crimes had been opened since August 2014, a reflection of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s authoritarian leadership style.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
The Lord of the Rings (Book Series)||Book Series
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR
item.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, reviewing an honor guard during a ceremonial reception in Abuja, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Swedish Girl, ISIS and a Cautionary Tale of Global Terrorism
item.description: The story of Marilyn Nevalainen stands out as a rare case in which a young European went unwittingly into the heart of jihadist territory and was freed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Office of The Chancellor Kurdistan Region Security Council, via Reuters
item.media:description: An undated photograph of Marilyn Nevalainen. The Swedish teenager ended up with Islamic State militants near Mosul, Iraq, with a new baby to care for and her boyfriend dead on the battlefield.

item.title: Jonathan Sacks, Britain’s Ex-Chief Rabbi, Wins Templeton Prize
item.description: The organization cited Rabbi Sacks’s efforts to counter religious extremism while “affirming life’s spiritual dimension.”
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Rabbi Jonathan Sacks was applauded by Jennifer Templeton Simpson of the John Templeton Foundation after winning the organization’s 2016 Prize.

item.title: Doubts Rise in Iran About Conclusive Election Results
item.description: Five days after national elections, the Interior Ministry has yet to release official detailed results, and the picture outside Tehran remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Iranian Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran visited an automobile industry show in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Shell and Nigerian Partner Are Sued in Britain Over Spills
item.description: Farmers and fishermen in the Niger Delta say they have suffered for years because of large spills from oil pipelines.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gaagaa Gidom, a 60 year-old fisherman and father of eight, looks at the spilled crude oil floating on the waters of the Niger Delta swamps.
